clusters.title: ABC ends Jimmy Kimmel suspension, show will return Tuesday
clusters.neutral_headline: Jimmy Kimmel Show Returns After Suspension

items.title: ABC ends Jimmy Kimmel suspension, show will return Tuesday
items.standfirst: Jimmy Kimmel's late night talk show, which was abruptly pulled from the air last week after the US government threatened broadcasters, will be back on Tuesday, Disney announced Monday.
items.content: Jimmy Kimmel's late night talk show, which was abruptly pulled from the air last week after the US government threatened broadcasters, will be back on Tuesday, Disney announced Monday.

items.title: Jimmy Kimmel supporters who pushed for Disney boycott take victory lap over his return to ABC
items.standfirst: Proponents of a boycott of the Walt Disney Co. over its decision to pull Jimmy Kimmel’s show last week after pressure from the White House took a victory lap on Monday after the company decided to return the late-night host to the air.

items.title: Jimmy Kimmel will be back on air on Tuesday, Disney says
items.standfirst: The late night comic was suspended last week under pressure from the Trump administration after comments about Charlie Kirk's killing.
items.content: The late night comic was suspended last week under pressure from the Trump administration after comments about Charlie Kirk's killing.(Image credit: Ronald Martinez)

items.title: Jimmy Kimmel show to return to the air on Tuesday after Charlie Kirk comments
items.standfirst: Late night talk show "Jimmy Kimmel Live" will return to its ABC network lineup on Tuesday, six days after the show was suspended following threats by the Federal Communications Commission chairman after comments the host made about the assassination of Charlie Kirk.
items.content: Late night talk show "Jimmy Kimmel Live" will return to its ABC network lineup on Tuesday, six days after the show was suspended following threats by the Federal Communications Commission chairman after comments the host made about the assassination of Charlie Kirk.

items.title: Disney says Jimmy Kimmel will return to air on Tuesday
items.standfirst: Kimmel was suspended last week for comments he made about the death of Charlie Kirk.
items.content: Disney announced “Jimmy Kimmel Live!” will resume airing on Tuesday, ending Kimmel's short-lived suspension following comments the host made on his show about the killing of Charlie Kirk. In a statement released Monday, Disney said it suspended Kimmel last week “to avoid inflaming a tense situation.” The company received intense pressure from Trump allies, including Federal Communications Commission Chair Brendan Carr, over Kimmel’s comments. “Last Wednesday, we made the decision to suspend production on the show to avoid further inflaming a tense situation at an emotional moment for our country,” Disney said in the statement. “It is a decision we made because we felt some of the comments were ill-timed and thus insensitive.” “We have spent the last days having thoughtful conversations with Jimmy, and after those conversations, we reached the decision to return the show on Tuesday,” the statement continued. Sinclair Broadcasting Group, which operates nearly 40 ABC affiliates, said Monday evening that it will preempt Kimmel's show on its stations when the show returns. Kimmel’s suspension set off a wave of criticism from leaders in both parties who were concerned about political censorship. Prior to Kimmel’s suspension, Carr condemned Kimmel’s comments and suggested that media companies who receive licensing from the FCC have “an obligation to operate in the public interest.” “We can do this the easy way or the hard way,” Carr said last Wednesday in an interview. Hours later on Wednesday, Nexstar Media Group and Sinclair Broadcasting Group, two of the nation’s largest owners of local television stations, said they would preempt tapings of “Jimmy Kimmel Live!” because of Kimmel’s comments. Nexstar Media Group is currently pursuing a billion-dollar merger with Tegna that would require FCC approval. The White House did not immediately respond to a request for comment. A handful of prominent Republicans on Capitol Hill, including Texas Sen. Ted Cruz, warned that Carr could set a dangerous precedent and urged the Trump administration to be careful in pressuring a private company to influence its speech. Democratic leaders in Washington and hundreds of artists and celebrities joined in condemning Kimmel’s suspension. FCC commissioner Anna Gomez, the lone Democrat in the agency's leadership, welcomed Kimmel's return to air and praised Americans who criticized the suspension. "I am glad to see Disney find its courage in the face of clear government intimidation," she said. Andrew Kolvet, a spokesperson for Turning Point USA, encouraged Nexstar and Sinclair to keep their pledge to preempt Kimmel when his show returns. “Disney and ABC caving and allowing Kimmell back on the air is not surprising, but it's their mistake to make,” Kolvet said in a social media post Monday. “Nextstar and Sinclair do not have to make the same choice.”

ai_summary: ABC announced Jimmy Kimmel's show will return on Tuesday after being pulled last week.
The suspension followed comments Kimmel made after Charlie Kirk's assassination.
Disney faced backlash and cited "thoughtful conversations" for the decision.
Supporters of a Disney boycott celebrated Kimmel's return to the air.
Sinclair Broadcasting Group may preempt the show while discussions with ABC continue.

clusters.title: 'Historic and courageous': reactions to France's recognition of Palestine
clusters.neutral_headline: France Recognizes Palestine, Calls for UN Force

items.title: 'Historic and courageous': reactions to France's recognition of Palestine
items.standfirst: France's recognition of a Palestinian state at the UN on Monday was hailed as a landmark move by allies and the Palestinian Authority, even as Israel and the United States voiced opposition.
items.content: France's recognition of a Palestinian state at the UN on Monday was hailed as a landmark move by allies and the Palestinian Authority, even as Israel and the United States voiced opposition.

items.title: France formally recognises Palestinian state
items.standfirst: More European countries are expected to make the same move, as President Macron said in UN "the time for peace has come".
items.content: More European countries are expected to make the same move, as President Macron said in UN "the time for peace has come".

items.title: France recognises Palestine and calls for UN force in Gaza
items.standfirst: Macron sets out plan for international stabilisation mission as Arab and Muslim leaders prepare to meet Trump in New YorkEmmanuel Macron has announced France’s official recognition of the State of Palestine, setting out a plan for a UN-mandated international stabilisation force in postwar Gaza that is expected to find support in many countries but not in Israel or the US.“The time has come to end the war in Gaza, the massacres and the death,” Macron said during a speech opening a special summit in the United Nations general assembly hall on Monday evening. “The time has come to do justice for the Palestinian people and thus to recognise the State of Palestine in Gaza, the West Bank and Jerusalem.” Continue reading...
items.content: Macron sets out plan for international stabilisation mission as Arab and Muslim leaders prepare to meet Trump in New YorkEmmanuel Macron has announced France’s official recognition of the State of Palestine, setting out a plan for a UN-mandated international stabilisation force in postwar Gaza that is expected to find support in many countries but not in Israel or the US.“The time has come to end the war in Gaza, the massacres and the death,” Macron said during a speech opening a special summit in the United Nations general assembly hall on Monday evening. “The time has come to do justice for the Palestinian people and thus to recognise the State of Palestine in Gaza, the West Bank and Jerusalem.” Continue reading...

items.title: Mounting cost of war on both Palestinians and Israel
items.standfirst: France has joined several of its European peers in formally recognising a Palestinian State. At a world summit in New York on Monday, President Emmanuel Macron called on the world to do everything it could to preserve the possibility of a two-state solution and outlined a framework for a "renewed Palestinian Authority". Nearly two years since it began the war has devastated the livelihoods of Palestinian people but also dealt a serious blow to Israel's economy.
items.content: France has joined several of its European peers in formally recognising a Palestinian State. At a world summit in New York on Monday, President Emmanuel Macron called on the world to do everything it could to preserve the possibility of a two-state solution and outlined a framework for a "renewed Palestinian Authority". Nearly two years since it began the war has devastated the livelihoods of Palestinian people but also dealt a serious blow to Israel's economy.

items.title: Joy to worry: Palestinians react to the recognition of their statehood
items.standfirst: As more countries recognise Palestine, Palestinians are waiting to see what impact this will have on their lives.
items.content: As more countries recognise Palestine, Palestinians are waiting to see what impact this will have on their lives.

items.title: France officially recognises Palestinian state at UN General Assembly
items.standfirst: France formally recognised Palestine as a state at the UN General Assembly on Monday, marking a major shift in French diplomacy. It comes after the United Kingdom, Canada, Australia and Portugal recognised Palestinian statehood Sunday, September 21.
items.content: France formally recognised Palestine as a state at the UN General Assembly on Monday, marking a major shift in French diplomacy. It comes after the United Kingdom, Canada, Australia and Portugal recognised Palestinian statehood Sunday, September 21.

items.title: Replay: France's Macron officially recognises state of Palestine at UN summit
items.standfirst: French President Emmanuel Macron on Monday recognised a Palestinian state at a UN summit aimed at galvanising support for a two-state solution to the Mideast conflict a day ahead of the 2025 UN General Assembly in New York.
items.content: French President Emmanuel Macron on Monday recognised a Palestinian state at a UN summit aimed at galvanising support for a two-state solution to the Mideast conflict a day ahead of the 2025 UN General Assembly in New York.

items.title: France among six more countries to formally recognise Palestinian statehood

items.title: ‘The time has come’: France recognises the state of Palestine at UN summit
items.standfirst: French President Emmanuel Macron on Monday recognised a Palestinian state at a UN summit aimed at galvanising support for a two-state solution to the Mideast conflict a day ahead of the 2025 UN General Assembly in New York. Macron has spearheaded a move that spurred other Western governments to take the landmark step that has infuriated Israel.
items.content: French President Emmanuel Macron on Monday recognised a Palestinian state at a UN summit aimed at galvanising support for a two-state solution to the Mideast conflict a day ahead of the 2025 UN General Assembly in New York. Macron has spearheaded a move that spurred other Western governments to take the landmark step that has infuriated Israel.

items.content: Several Western nations have formally recognised Palestine, drawing praise from Palestinians.

items.content: France prepares to join UK in recognising Palestinian state.

items.title: Italy cautious on Palestinian recognition as protests grow
items.standfirst: On Monday, cities across Italy witnessed pro-Palestinian protests, strikes, and blockades, following union calls to “denounce the genocide in Gaza” and push for diplomatic and economic sanctions against Israel. Meanwhile, while neighbouring countries such as the UK and France move to recognise Palestinian statehood, the Italian government has opted for a more cautious approach.
items.content: On Monday, cities across Italy witnessed pro-Palestinian protests, strikes, and blockades, following union calls to “denounce the genocide in Gaza” and push for diplomatic and economic sanctions against Israel. Meanwhile, while neighbouring countries such as the UK and France move to recognise Palestinian statehood, the Italian government has opted for a more cautious approach.

items.title: Disruption across Italy as tens of thousands protest against Gaza war
items.standfirst: Schools and stations closed and ports blocked in one of Europe’s biggest demonstrations opposing Israel’s offensiveTens of thousands of people have taken to the streets in dozens of cities across Italy – shutting schools, disrupting trains and blocking ports and roads – in one of Europe’s largest nationwide protests against Israel’s offensive in Gaza.The protests came as France and several other countries prepared to recognise Palestinian statehood at the UN general assembly on Monday after the UK, Australia, Portugal and Canada did so on Sunday. Continue reading...
items.content: Schools and stations closed and ports blocked in one of Europe’s biggest demonstrations opposing Israel’s offensiveTens of thousands of people have taken to the streets in dozens of cities across Italy – shutting schools, disrupting trains and blocking ports and roads – in one of Europe’s largest nationwide protests against Israel’s offensive in Gaza.The protests came as France and several other countries prepared to recognise Palestinian statehood at the UN general assembly on Monday after the UK, Australia, Portugal and Canada did so on Sunday. Continue reading...

items.standfirst: The U.K., Canada and Australia formally recognized a Palestinian state, sparking fury from Israel ahead of a UNGA summit amid the Gaza war.
items.content: The U.K., Canada and Australia formally recognized a Palestinian state, sparking fury from Israel ahead of a UNGA summit amid the Gaza war.

items.standfirst: The UK, Australia and Canada have recognised a Palestinian state, while France and other countries are set to do so in the coming days.

The war has devastated Palestinian livelihoods and hurt Israel's economy.

items.standfirst: Copenhagen airport, the busiest in the Nordic region, reopened early on Tuesday after drones halted take-offs and landings for nearly four hoursAirports in Norway and Denmark faced hours of disruption after drone sightings caused flight delays and cancellations, with police in both countries pledging to cooperate in their investigations of the incidents.Copenhagen airport – the busiest in the Nordic region – reopened early on Tuesday after drone sightings halted take-offs and landings for nearly four hours, the airport said. Continue reading...

The fireworks display, called the “Ascending Dragon,” was staged…
items.content: HONG KONG — Officials in Tibet are investigating after the Canadian outdoor apparel brand Arc’teryx set off fireworks in the Himalayas in a publicity stunt that was widely criticized over its potential impact on the environment. The fireworks display, called the “Ascending Dragon,” was staged…

items.title: Arc’teryx fireworks display in Tibet prompts environmental outcry
items.standfirst: Outdoor brand says the Rising Dragon promotional event was out of line with its values after public criticismThe outdoor brand Arc’teryx has issued an apology after a promotional fireworks display in the Tibetan plateau led to an outcry over potential environmental damage.The promotional Rising Dragon high-altitude show involved long stretches of choreographed pyrotechnics and coloured smoke along snow-topped Himalayan ridgelines in the Tibetan region of Shigatse. The Canadian company, part-owned by China’s Anta Group, had partnered with a Chinese artist, Cai Guo-Qiang, who oversaw similar shows for the 2008 Beijing Olympics. Continue reading...
items.content: Outdoor brand says the Rising Dragon promotional event was out of line with its values after public criticismThe outdoor brand Arc’teryx has issued an apology after a promotional fireworks display in the Tibetan plateau led to an outcry over potential environmental damage.The promotional Rising Dragon high-altitude show involved long stretches of choreographed pyrotechnics and coloured smoke along snow-topped Himalayan ridgelines in the Tibetan region of Shigatse. The Canadian company, part-owned by China’s Anta Group, had partnered with a Chinese artist, Cai Guo-Qiang, who oversaw similar shows for the 2008 Beijing Olympics. Continue reading...

Kenvue, the maker of Tylenol, says rigorous research “confirms there is no credible evidence linking acetaminophen to autism”. NBC News’ Anne…

items.title: Experts alarmed as Trump pushes unproven link between Tylenol and autism
items.standfirst: Doctors call president’s warning that pregnant women should limit use of acetaminophen – also known as paracetamol - ‘highly concerning’ and ‘irresponsible’Medical experts are raising alarms after Donald Trump warned pregnant women to avoid taking Tylenol, baselessly linking the painkiller – also known as paracetamol - with a rise in autism among children.From the Society for Maternal-Fetal Medicine (SMFM) to the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists (ACOG), doctors have endorsed the use of acetaminophen during pregnancy after Trump said pregnant women who can’t “tough it out” without the painkiller should limit their intake. Continue reading...
items.content: Doctors call president’s warning that pregnant women should limit use of acetaminophen – also known as paracetamol - ‘highly concerning’ and ‘irresponsible’Medical experts are raising alarms after Donald Trump warned pregnant women to avoid taking Tylenol, baselessly linking the painkiller – also known as paracetamol - with a rise in autism among children.From the Society for Maternal-Fetal Medicine (SMFM) to the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists (ACOG), doctors have endorsed the use of acetaminophen during pregnancy after Trump said pregnant women who can’t “tough it out” without the painkiller should limit their intake. Continue reading...

items.content: President Donald Trump made unproven statements on autism rates during a health announcement on Tylenol usage and pregnancy.

items.title: Co-author of study on acetaminophen use during pregnancy says more research is needed
items.standfirst: President Trump on Monday suggested a possible link between the use of acetaminophen during pregnancy and an increased risk of autism in children. Dr. Ann Bauer, co-author of a study that examined acetaminophen use during pregnancy, explains why more research is needed. Then, Dr. Veronica Gillispie-Bell, a board-certified OBGYN, joins to unpack the news.
items.content: President Trump on Monday suggested a possible link between the use of acetaminophen during pregnancy and an increased risk of autism in children. Dr. Ann Bauer, co-author of a study that examined acetaminophen use during pregnancy, explains why more research is needed. Then, Dr. Veronica Gillispie-Bell, a board-certified OBGYN, joins to unpack the news.

items.title: Doctor reacts to Trump's announcement about Tylenol and autism

items.title: Rodrigo Duterte, former Philippines president, charged with crimes against humanity at ICC
items.standfirst: Three charges against Duterte stem from his years-long campaign against drug users and dealers that rights groups say killed thousandsProsecutors at the international criminal court (ICC) have charged former Philippines president Rodrigo Duterte with three counts of crimes against humanity, alleging his involvement in at least 76 murders as part of his “war on drugs”.A heavily redacted charge sheet dated 4 July but made public on Monday laid out the accusations against the 80-year-old former leader, who is in ICC detention in The Hague. Continue reading...

items.title: Trump's New H-1B Visa Cost Could Hurt US Tech Companies
items.standfirst: US tech companies could have a harder time attracting foreign workers after President Donald Trump raised the application fee for H-1B visa's to $100,000. After Trump made the announcement late Friday, some companies had to tell affected employees to return to the US right away and to not travel overseas. Bloomberg's Michael Shepard reports. (Source: Bloomberg)

Continue reading...

items.title: Trump’s Fed pick doubles down on calls to aggressively cut interest rates
items.standfirst: Stephen Miran says rates should be below 3% by end of year and dismisses fears of US president’s tariffs stoking inflationStephen Miran, Donald Trump’s new appointee on the Federal Reserve’s interest-rate-setting board, has doubled down on his calls for the central bank to more aggressively cut interest rates.Last week, the Fed cut interest rates by a quarter point, bringing rates down to a range of 4% to 4.25% – the lowest it’s been since early 2023. Out of 12 voting board members, Miran was the only one to vote against the crowd. He wanted a half-point cut, not a quarter-point cut. Continue reading...
items.content: Stephen Miran says rates should be below 3% by end of year and dismisses fears of US president’s tariffs stoking inflationStephen Miran, Donald Trump’s new appointee on the Federal Reserve’s interest-rate-setting board, has doubled down on his calls for the central bank to more aggressively cut interest rates.Last week, the Fed cut interest rates by a quarter point, bringing rates down to a range of 4% to 4.25% – the lowest it’s been since early 2023. Out of 12 voting board members, Miran was the only one to vote against the crowd. He wanted a half-point cut, not a quarter-point cut. Continue reading...

clusters.title: Palestinian statehood condemned by Israeli officials brings a 'glimmer of hope' for some Palestinians
clusters.neutral_headline: Palestinian statehood condemned by Israeli officials brings a 'glimmer of hope' for some Palestinians

items.title: Palestinian statehood condemned by Israeli officials brings a 'glimmer of hope' for some Palestinians
items.standfirst: As Palestinians and much of the Arab and Muslim worlds praised the decision by several European countries to recognize Palestinian statehood, Israeli politicians across the political spectrum reacted with anger and spoke of retaliation.“You are giving a huge prize to terrorism,” Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said in a recorded address released Sunday night, as countries including the United Kingdom, Canada and Australia began to express their commitments to Palestinian statehood.
items.content: As Palestinians and much of the Arab and Muslim worlds praised the decision by several European countries to recognize Palestinian statehood, Israeli politicians across the political spectrum reacted with anger and spoke of retaliation.“You are giving a huge prize to terrorism,” Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said in a recorded address released Sunday night, as countries including the United Kingdom, Canada and Australia began to express their commitments to Palestinian statehood.

items.title: Majority of Israelis opposed to two-state solution
items.standfirst: A vast majority of countries represented at the United Nations already recognize a Palestinian state. With others now joining that number, Israel is becoming more and more isolated on the international stage. But public opinion inside Israel remains steadfastly opposed, with only a small minority supporting a two-state solution. FRANCE 24’s Claire Duhamel and Mohamed Farhat filed this report near the Israeli border with Gaza.
items.content: A vast majority of countries represented at the United Nations already recognize a Palestinian state. With others now joining that number, Israel is becoming more and more isolated on the international stage. But public opinion inside Israel remains steadfastly opposed, with only a small minority supporting a two-state solution. FRANCE 24’s Claire Duhamel and Mohamed Farhat filed this report near the Israeli border with Gaza.

items.title: Why recognise a Palestinian state?
items.standfirst: France is set to officially recognise the State of Palestine at the United Nations summit, joining countries such as the UK, Canada, Australia, and Portugal, which have already taken the step. The move is being framed as a symbolic gesture to support a two-state solution and push for renewed diplomatic efforts between Israel and Palestine. Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has lashed out at the decision, insisting that a Palestinian state will not happen. FRANCE 24's Douglas Herbert ponder on why it is important to recognize a Palestinian state even though it's mainly symbolic.
items.content: France is set to officially recognise the State of Palestine at the United Nations summit, joining countries such as the UK, Canada, Australia, and Portugal, which have already taken the step. The move is being framed as a symbolic gesture to support a two-state solution and push for renewed diplomatic efforts between Israel and Palestine. Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has lashed out at the decision, insisting that a Palestinian state will not happen. FRANCE 24's Douglas Herbert ponder on why it is important to recognize a Palestinian state even though it's mainly symbolic.

ai_summary: Several European countries recognized Palestinian statehood.
Israeli politicians reacted with anger and spoke of retaliation.
Israeli Prime Minister Netanyahu condemned the decision.
Public opinion in Israel remains opposed to a two-state solution.
The move is framed as a symbolic gesture.

items.title: Reeves urged to take 2p off employee NI and add it to income tax in budget
items.standfirst: Resolution Foundation says move could raise additional £6bn a year and ‘level the playing field’ on income taxRachel Reeves has been urged to take 2p off the rate of employee national insurance and add it to income tax in her autumn budget, to raise billions of pounds while protecting workers’ pay packets.Putting forward plans to raise up to £30bn, the influential Resolution Foundation thinktank called on the chancellor to “level the playing field” on how different forms of income are taxed. Continue reading...

items.standfirst: Nationwide survey in London, Manchester and Glasgow shows pandemic trends may be reversing as more people return to office People buying homes in London 500 metres from a tube or railway station pay £42,700 more than buyers of similar properties 1,500 metres away from transport hubs, according to…
items.content: Nationwide survey in London, Manchester and Glasgow shows pandemic trends may be reversing as more people return to office People buying homes in London 500 metres from a tube or railway station pay £42,700 more than buyers of similar properties 1,500 metres away from transport hubs, according to…

items.title: London homes 500 metres from station ‘command £42,700 premium over those 1,500 metres away’
items.standfirst: Nationwide survey in London, Manchester and Glasgow shows pandemic trends may be reversing as more people return to officePeople buying homes in London 500 metres from a tube or railway station pay £42,700 more than buyers of similar properties 1,500 metres away from transport hubs, according to new data.The figures indicate that despite the reshaping of the housing market sparked by the coronavirus pandemic and dramatic changes to working patterns, the traditional estate agent mantra of “good transport links” continues to wield its power over buyers. Continue reading...
items.content: Nationwide survey in London, Manchester and Glasgow shows pandemic trends may be reversing as more people return to officePeople buying homes in London 500 metres from a tube or railway station pay £42,700 more than buyers of similar properties 1,500 metres away from transport hubs, according to new data.The figures indicate that despite the reshaping of the housing market sparked by the coronavirus pandemic and dramatic changes to working patterns, the traditional estate agent mantra of “good transport links” continues to wield its power over buyers. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Homes near London stations cost £42,700 more.
The survey included London, Manchester, and Glasgow.
The data suggests pandemic trends may be reversing.
The premium is for homes 500 meters from a station.
The survey was conducted by Nationwide.

William Brangham discussed those claims and the concerns about what the president said with Dr. Alycia Halladay of the Autism Science Foundation and Jennifer Nuzzo of Brown…
items.content: President Trump tied the use of acetaminophen during pregnancy to autism and made several other claims about vaccines. William Brangham discussed those claims and the concerns about what the president said with Dr. Alycia Halladay of the Autism Science Foundation and Jennifer Nuzzo of Brown…

items.title: Trump blames Tylenol for autism. Science doesn't back him up
items.standfirst: President Trump and his deputies tied autism to acetaminophen use during pregnancy, presented a cancer drug as a possible treatment, and said the FDA would change labeling to reflect both claims. There is little strong scientific evidence for either.
items.content: President Trump and his deputies tied autism to acetaminophen use during pregnancy, presented a cancer drug as a possible treatment, and said the FDA would change labeling to reflect both claims. There is little strong scientific evidence for either. (Image credit: Andrew Harnik)

clusters.title: Syria’s al-Sharaa renews call for US to formally drop sanctions

items.title: Syria’s al-Sharaa renews call for US to formally drop sanctions
items.standfirst: President Ahmed al-Sharaa meets US secretary of state in New York as he prepares to attend UN General Assembly meetings.
items.content: President Ahmed al-Sharaa meets US secretary of state in New York as he prepares to attend UN General Assembly meetings.

items.title: Syria’s Sharaa baulks at Abraham Accords with Israel during New York visit
items.standfirst: At a summit in New York on the sidelines of the UN General Assembly meeting on Monday, Syrian President Ahmed al-Sharaa said he was hopeful about security talks with Israel. But when asked if Syria would join the Abraham Accords, under which three Arab nations normalised relations with Israel, Sharaa voiced doubts about Israel's regional intentions.
items.content: At a summit in New York on the sidelines of the UN General Assembly meeting on Monday, Syrian President Ahmed al-Sharaa said he was hopeful about security talks with Israel. But when asked if Syria would join the Abraham Accords, under which three Arab nations normalised relations with Israel, Sharaa voiced doubts about Israel's regional intentions.

ai_summary: Syrian President Ahmed al-Sharaa met with the US Secretary of State.
Al-Sharaa attended UN General Assembly meetings.
Al-Sharaa expressed doubts about Israel's regional intentions.
Al-Sharaa is hopeful about security talks with Israel.
Al-Sharaa renewed his call for the US to drop sanctions.

clusters.title: France: Trial begins for Cédric Jubillar over wife’s disappearance
clusters.neutral_headline: French trial begins for man accused of wife's murder

items.title: France: Trial begins for Cédric Jubillar over wife’s disappearance
items.standfirst: The trial of Cédric Jubillar has started in France over the disappearance of his wife, Delphine, in December 2020. He is accused of her murder despite the body never being found and continues to claim his innocence. Evidence includes alleged threats, forensic traces, and inconsistencies in his phone records.
items.content: The trial of Cédric Jubillar has started in France over the disappearance of his wife, Delphine, in December 2020. He is accused of her murder despite the body never being found and continues to claim his innocence. Evidence includes alleged threats, forensic traces, and inconsistencies in his phone records.

items.title: France transfixed by murder trial without a body
items.standfirst: Cédric Jubillar has always denied killing his wife Delphine, who vanished in December 2020.
items.content: Cédric Jubillar has always denied killing his wife Delphine, who vanished in December 2020.

ai_summary: Cédric Jubillar's trial started in France regarding his wife's disappearance in 2020.
He is accused of murder, despite the body never being found by authorities.
Jubillar maintains his innocence, denying any involvement in his wife's disappearance.
Evidence includes alleged threats, forensic traces, and phone record inconsistencies.
Delphine Jubillar vanished in December 2020, leading to the ongoing investigation.

clusters.title: British couple held by Taliban for months feared they would be executed

items.title: British couple held by Taliban for months feared they would be executed
items.standfirst: Peter and Barbie Reynolds, 80 and 76, said it was never explained to them why they were being held.
items.content: Peter and Barbie Reynolds, 80 and 76, said it was never explained to them why they were being held.

items.title: British couple released after detention in Afghanistan say they feared being executed
items.standfirst: Barbie Reynolds, 76, and husband Peter, 80, said it was never explained to them why they were imprisonedA British couple who were reunited with their family in the UK after being released from almost eight months in detention in Afghanistan have said they feared being executed by the Taliban.Peter Reynolds, 80, and his wife, Barbie, 76, who arrived at Heathrow on Saturday, said it was never explained to them why they were imprisoned in Afghanistan after their arrest in February. Continue reading...
items.content: Barbie Reynolds, 76, and husband Peter, 80, said it was never explained to them why they were imprisonedA British couple who were reunited with their family in the UK after being released from almost eight months in detention in Afghanistan have said they feared being executed by the Taliban.Peter Reynolds, 80, and his wife, Barbie, 76, who arrived at Heathrow on Saturday, said it was never explained to them why they were imprisoned in Afghanistan after their arrest in February. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Peter and Barbie Reynolds, aged 80 and 76, were held by the Taliban for months.
The couple stated they were never told why they were being held in Afghanistan.
They were released after almost eight months of detention in Afghanistan.
The Reynolds feared they would be executed by the Taliban during their detention.
They arrived at Heathrow after being released from their imprisonment.
